content.description: 5Easy start with a dynamic Crux near top and continues thin to anchors.
content.protection: Safe bolting with a Rap hanger and chain.

content.description: The crux of this climb is an excellent and difficult 12-foot boulder problem in the obvious overhang that is punctuated by a lunge or a dyno depending on your reach.  Having the words "Ripped My Flesh" in the name is appropriate as the rock is very sharp.
content.location: Directly right of the black water streak of Burnt Weenie Sandwich, in roughly the center of the big overhang.

climbs.name: We're Only In It For the Money

content.description: Easy start on 5.7 type holds. The route moves onto slab just below a bulge. The holds get even thinner moving up to and over a second bulge which is probably the crux. The route remains solidly on 5.10a climbing on up to the anchors.
content.protection: Nine bolts. One hanger and one chain for anchors.
content.location: Fifth route from the right on Zappa Dome

content.description: Blocky 5.7 climbing for about 40 feet leads to a tricky bulge.  Near the top of the route is a tenuous slab section.
content.location: Left of Mud Shark, right of Conceptual Continuity.

content.description: This route starts left of, and crosses over, One Size Fits All. The route is nicely sustained 5.5 and very safely bolted. A good opportunity for compression moves under a roof down low, and fairly steep airy climbing above keep it interesting.
content.protection: Nine bolts. One hanger and one chain for anchors.
content.location: Second route from the right on Zappa Dome

content.description: Easy start on 5.6 type holds. The route moves onto slab as the wall steepens. The route moves slightly left on a small bulge, then over a larger bulge for the crux and onto thinner but not as vertical slab up to the anchors.
content.protection: Nine bolts. One hanger and one chain for anchors.
content.location: Fourth route from the right on Zappa Dome

content.description: First route from the left.  Difficult but well-protected bouldery start.  From there, walk up to the wall for a short section of fun face climbing.  Well, I thought it was fun anyway..  The 2nd halves of this one and the one to the right are reminiscent of Rad Wall climbing.
5easy start with crux near top and continues thin to anchors.
content.location: 7th route from Token, Start near base of tree

content.description: This route starts right of, and crosses over, Token of My Extreme. The trickiest part runs just left of an obvious water stain. There is a height dependent crux in this nearly vertical zone that favors taller climbers. Climbing remains tricky up to a large pocket and bulge, then become less vertical with easier holds to the anchors.
content.protection: Eight bolts. One hanger and one chain for anchors.

content.description: A few gigantic holds gets you onto a shelf where the fun begins. The shelf yields some interesting handholds in not-so-obvious places. There is no real crux, but the move off the shelf back onto the face will be a little thrilling for new 5.7 leaders. As you move higher, the grade remains sustained and challenging on classic Cochise granite.
content.protection: 9 bolts. One hanger and one chain for anchors.
content.location: Seventh route from the left on Zappa Dome. Two routes to the left of the obvious black streak on Burnt Weenie Sandwich.

content.description:
Most folks tend to visually divide Zappa Wall into left, middle and right sides.  The left routes are 1-8 on the topo, middle would be 9, 10 & 11 and then the right side would be from 12 on over.   

  This route is the right-most of the middle section and heads up the corner above the big angled ledge two routes over from the black streak route (Burnt Weenie Sandwich) then cuts out left onto the last bit of the overhanging face.  The route is characterized by many as having a height - dependent crux.
content.location: Two routes to the right from black water streak in middle of wall.  Belay down and left from lower cove or up on ledge to the right directly below route.

content.description: The start is very technical... limited choices to send... a lot of matching. From there moderate climbing to a higher crux which is tricky but the moves are there... you just have to find them... overall 5.9+ is an averaged rating... 5.10b moves at crux on lead.
content.protection: 9 bolts with 2 bolts at top one with a chain
content.location: 2nd route from left next to a tree

climbs.name: It Might Just Be A One-Shot Deal

content.description: A few careful moves gets you onto some easy low-angle climbing. The route moves up to a distinct patch of clean, whitish-colored rock. The crux involves a safe, but committing, move getting around that patch back onto the face. Above the fourth bolt the face thins out considerably, but with some positive hand holds right where you need them. The anchors are in a very blank section of rock with small foot holds and no useful hand holds.
content.protection: 9 bolts. One hanger and one chain for anchors
content.location: Fourth route from the left on Zappa Dome. Starts at a tree which provides a shady belay.

content.description: Steep face climbing for almost the entire 60 feet.  Jug hauling down low and some tricky moves up high.
content.location: Left of the black water streak of Burnth Weenie Sandwich and right of Mud Shark.

content.description: Starts up a walk-up 'gully' to first bolt then heads up through a sustained section of face climbing with very positive holds and tight bolt spacing.  Eases up considerably as it heads to the anchors past the low angle line.  Crux is probably the no rest section across the first three or so bolts.  FWIW, most folks find this route a bit sandbagged at 5.8.

The first bolt is high, but 5.8 leaders should have no problem reaching it. Easy start on low-angle 5.5 type holds. The route moves onto slab as the wall steepens. The route stays on nearly vertical slab climbing to the roof. The crux is probably a thin, airy move just above the roof. It continues on slab to the anchors but is less vertical.
content.protection: Eight bolts. One hanger and one chain for anchors.
content.location: Third route from the right on Zappa Dome

content.description: One move wonder with most of the route falling in the 5.6-7 range.  A short, slightly overhanging section in the middle earns it the 5.9.  Big, positive holds through here will keep you happy but be careful not to spend too much time figuring out the feet.
content.location: Fifth route from the left.  First route out of the shaded cove, left side area.  Heads up to obvious, flat overhanging face.

content.description: A tricky and slippery start leads to some awkward moves over a lip, then some positive holds up a steep face to finish on less than vertical terrain. You may find yourself trending pretty far left for better holds and a rest near the lip. If you do this the route is 5.10. If you don't the route is 10+ maybe even 11- and contrived, though either way is fun.
content.location: Directly right of Grand Wazoo and on the left side of the big overhang. Follows a black water streak for much of the route.

content.description:
More sport climbing in the Stronghold.  The rock here is more interesting (IMO) than Isle of You, and the bolt spacing is much closer (both vertically, and horizontally).  You can decide for yourself if this is a good thing.  With the exception of just a few bolts near protectable cracks, most of the bolting is quite good on a solid and unbroken face.  This is a predominantly moderate area with most of the routes in the 5.9 to 5.11 range.  South facing and warm, with little shade.  Beware, in places the rock is still a bit flaky.   

  I believe that most of these routes were put up by the prolific Scott Ayers.
